msDesc.head:
Miscellany works on Computus and astrology N. France or Ramsey Abbey(?) s.XIex-XIIin
Digital facsimile at www.bl.uk.

msItem.incipit: Cum quibus fratribus nostris adolescentioribus quedam calculatoriae artis
msItem.explicit: doctorum sublimiora rimetur.

msItem.incipit: Annus solaris ut maiorum constat sollertia inuestigatum
msItem.explicit: illa deinceps facilius assequantur.

msItem.title: Dies Egyptiaci
msItem.incipit: Si tenebre Ä™giptus graio sermone uocatur
msItem.explicit: mortale periculum est sanguinem minuere.

msItem.note: Computus material including Ciclus annalis, De horis mensium and De singulis horis in die quomodo mensurantur cum pedibus with a table of moveable feasts (f. 13r) and an orologium diagram.

msItem.incipit: Arsista apud hebreos siros et chaldeos nimiam uocatur
msItem.note: Computistical table for the moveable feasts.

msItem.incipit: Ianuarius et december hora I et XI pedes XXIX
msItem.explicit: Iunius et Iulius hora I et XV pedes XIX.

msItem.rubric: Item de singulis horis in die quomodo mensurantur cum pedibus
msItem.incipit: Coniunge semper duos menses coequales
msItem.explicit: longitudine dierum et uario statu umbrarum.

msItem.incipit: Ianuarius et december hora I et XI pedes XXVIIII, hora II et X pedes XIX
msItem.explicit: hora VI pedem I.

msItem.author: Bede
msItem.title: De natura rerum
msItem.rubric: Incipiunt duo libelli Bede presbiteri de natura rerum et ratione temporum. Incipit liber primus de quadrifario dei opere
msItem.incipit: Operatio divina que secula creavit et gubernat
msItem.explicit: atque inde affrica a meridie usque ad occidentem excenditur.
msItem.note: Marginal annotation on f. 16r: Quando luna plena est uix stelle uidentur in caelo quia superat tunc lux lune lumen stellarum et si defectus illius fuerit quia tunc accidere solet statim apparent. Similiter si in die fuerit defectus solis omnes eadem hora possunt uideri. Si quando oriuntur truces seui que uenticuta etherem rapiunt scintillas ex ethereo igne et sic uidetur quasi stelle cadant.

msItem.author: Bede
msItem.title: De temporibus
msItem.rubric: Incipit secundus de temporibus horis et momentis
msItem.incipit: Tempora momentis horis diebus mensibus annis saeculis Ä™tatibus diuiduntur
msItem.explicit: Reliquum sexte etatis deo soli patet finis.

msItem.title: Apuleian Sphere
msItem.incipit: Pitoris (corrected to: Pitorisis) Necnepso regi salutem. De his que a me ad humane vite

msItem.rubric: Incipit prologus in libro Bede de temporibus III.
msItem.incipit: De natura rerum et ratione temporum duos quondam
msItem.explicit: fraternitatis intemerata iura custodiat.

msItem.rubric: Incipit liber tertius de compoto vel loquela digitorum.
msItem.explicit: mereamur accipere palmam.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber Bede resbiteri de temporibus tertius

msItem.title: Excerptum de astrologia
msItem.incipit: Duo sunt vertices mundi quos appelant polos
msItem.explicit: ad ipsum usque decurrit accipiens.

msItem.title: Excerptio Abbonis ex higino de figuratione signorum
msItem.author: Abbo of Fleury
msItem.incipit: Denique ut dicit plinius inter omnia sunt LXXIIta signa
msItem.explicit: secans ad octauam partem cancri redit.

msItem.author: Abbo of Fleury
msItem.title: Sententia Abbonis de differentia circuli et sperae
msItem.incipit: Studiosis astrologiÄ™ primo sciendum est
msItem.explicit: Si vero nota est aliquis planetarum est.

msItem.author: Abbo of Fleury
msItem.incipit: Denique luna totius zodiaci signa puncta partes studiooso lectori manifestabit
msItem.explicit: similiter in reliquis.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber arati de signis celestibus.
msItem.decoNote: Diagram of the lunar motion on f.14v.

msItem.title: De duodecim signis
msItem.rubric: De XII signis cur figurantur sic de ariete
msItem.incipit: Regionem primam celi in qua sol cursum suum dirigit
msItem.explicit: ac si numquam fuissent audita vel scripta penitus omittenda, quae diabolicus error confirmavit sed christus dominus salvator mundi evertit.
msItem.decoNote: Diagram of the rising and setting of the sun throughout the year.

msItem.title: On the celestial circles and the postiton of the constellations
msItem.incipit: Spera fiat omni parte equalis et rotunda
msItem.explicit: leua manu ipsius serpentis pectus stringens flexuosu.

msItem.author: Dungal
msItem.title: Epistola ad Carolum Magnum de duplici solis eclipsi anno 810
msItem.note: The middle section of Dunagl's text is replaced with an excerpt from Macrobius' Commentary. According to Stansfield, Alcuins achievement, the text of the letter is closely related to but at some points superior to the copy in Berlin, SB Cod. 1831, ff. 116-117. Additions starting from, f. 122v-123 from Macrobius with diagram.
Dungal's letter (MGH Epp. IV, pp. 570-573 line 29)
msItem.incipit: In nomine patris et filii et spiritus sancti. Domino gloriosissimo Karolo serenissimo augusto
msItem.explicit: mox oritur aries in quo sol ante.

msItem.author: Macrobius
msItem.title: Commentarium in Ciceronis somnium Scipionis (excerpts from Lib. II, cap. 7, Â§ 5-21 and cap. 8, Â§ 1-8)
msItem.incipit: his depictis sine dificultate constabit singulas terre partes
msItem.explicit: quid possit amplius pro absoluenda hac questione conferri.
msItem.decoNote: Diagram of the celestial and terrestrial sphere, divided by five circles and the zodiac.

msItem.note: Continuation of Dungal's letter (MGH Epp. IV, from p. 576 line 27 until the end).
msItem.incipit: Igitur sicut annum solis non solum a kalendis
msItem.explicit: sed et piissime adque amantissime pater.

msItem.author: Isidore of Seville
msItem.note: Extracts from Etymologiae, book 3, De eclipse, chapters 58 and 59.
msItem.incipit: Eclipsis solis est quotiens luna trigesima ad eandem lineam

msItem.author: Macrobius
msItem.note: Extracts on astronomical subjects from Commentarii in Ciceronis Somnium Scipionis.
Anonymous, treatise on the method of computation with examples.
msItem.incipit: Si vis scire quot sint anni ab incarnatione

msItem.rubric: De notis antiquioribus que notant numerus
msItem.note: extract from Rabanus Maurus, De computo, chapter 6:
msItem.incipit: Tres digiti in sinistra manu, id est auricularis

msItem.author: De mensuris et ponderibus
msItem.incipit: Mensurarum in liquidis coclear est pars minima
Compotus hic alphabeto confectus habetur

msItem.note: A short text on the moveable feasts followed by a diagram on the epacts allowing to find the date in the lunar calendar from the solar calendar; it is used in the calculation of the date of Easter.

msItem.author: Bede
msItem.title: Epistola ad Wicthedum de aequinoctio vel de paschae celebratione
msItem.note: imperfect at the beginning and at the end
msItem.incipit: equinoctialem sui cursus locum in signifero circulo
msItem.explicit: aut nona kalendarum aprilium die non fuisse, aut ante equinoctium fuisse confirmet
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit Epistola Bede presbiteri ad Vicredam presbiterum

msItem.note: verses on the seven liberal arts. The last verses have been copied by two different 15th-century hands (f. 149v).

layoutDesc.layout:
(41 written lines on ff. 1-10, 21 on ff. 11-)
190 105

decoDesc.decoNote: Nine large initials in green, red and yellow colours with zoomorphic motifs (ff. 1r, 1v, 14v, 22r, 30v, 32v, 104r, 105r, 120r).

44 drawings of the constellations in braun and red ink(105r-112v). The drawings had been made before the text was copied. They are placed on the side of the text-body, usually in the inner half of the page. The figures of the constellations have circles partly matching the place where according to the text stars are. It is possible that the artist misunderstood the model manuscript and mistook the star marking for clothes decoration.
One explanatory drawing of methods of calculation of the Computus (f. 33v). Ten diagrams and tables in brown and red ink (ff. 14r, 29v, 114v, 118r, 123r, 127v, 143v, 144r, 144v, 145v).

history.origin: The manuscripts was written either in Ramsey Abbey or in Northern France in end of the eleventh or beginning of the twelfth century.
history.provenance: On the later hisstory and acquisition of the manuscript see the catalogue of illuminated manuscripts .
